comment_text.mn45:3.3: This view is said to be a cause for lower rebirth at AN 3.113:1.5, an addiction at AN 3.156:1.6, and an extreme at Ud 6.8:5.4.
comment_text.mn45:3.5: Moḷibaddha (“head-band”) appears as a bejeweled decoration for lay folk at Mil 6.1.3:1.3 and Mil 6.4.2:4.2, and with a list of garbs for ascetics at Mil 5.1.6:12.5. The Sanskrit maulibandha appears in a few later texts in the same sense. None of these sources clarify who these fancy wanderer ladies might be. The Chinese parallel at MA 174, however, does not say they are wanderers. It does seem odd to find such a decorative detail being worn by wanderers, so perhaps the Pali text is confused, and the idea of wanderers wearing headbands was later adopted by the Milinda. On the other hand, later texts such as the comedy Mattavilāsaprahasana show that dissolute “renunciates” were not unknown.
comment_text.mn45:4.1: The “camel’s foot creeper” (māluvā) features in a similar simile in the Jain Sūyagaḍa 1.3.2.10.
comment_text.mn45:4.6: On “eaten by termites”, Bhikkhu Ñāṇatusita, whose expertise in Pali is rivaled only by his knowledge of botany, says in his notes to Bhikkhu Bodhi’s translation, “Perhaps even the whole seed was eaten since the Maloo Creeper, a member of the legume family, has a hard woody seed. It is eaten by forest people in India, supposedly after removing the skin. Termites do not carry away seeds like ants would do, they eat things at the spot. Besides this, the seed is quite large. Thus udrabheyyuṁ is probably the right reading. It is supported by the commentary, which glosses it as khādeyyuṁ.”
comment_text.mn45:6.5: Described as someone who “goes against the stream” at AN 4.5:2.2, and as worthy of praise at AN 5.5:2.4.

root_text.mn45:3.1: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhaṁ āyatiṁ dukkhavipākaṁ?
root_text.mn45:3.2: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
root_text.mn45:3.7: ‘kiṁsu nāma te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kāmesu anāgatabhayaṁ sampassamānā kāmānaṁ pahānamāhaṁsu, kāmānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapenti?
root_text.mn45:3.8: Sukho imissā paribbājikāya taruṇāya mudukāya lomasāya bāhāya samphasso’ti te kāmesu pātabyataṁ āpajjanti.
root_text.mn45:3.9: Te kāmesu pātabyataṁ āpajjitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjanti.
root_text.mn45:3.10: Te tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti.
root_text.mn45:3.12: ‘idaṁ kho te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā kāmesu anāgatabhayaṁ sampassamānā kāmānaṁ pahānamāhaṁsu, kāmānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapenti, ime hi mayaṁ kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayāmā’ti.
root_text.mn45:4.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gimhānaṁ pacchime māse māluvāsipāṭikā phaleyya.
root_text.mn45:4.2: Atha kho taṁ, bhikkhave, māluvābījaṁ aññatarasmiṁ sālamūle nipateyya.
root_text.mn45:4.3: Atha kho, bhikkhave, yā tasmiṁ sāle adhivatthā devatā sā bhītā saṁviggā santāsaṁ āpajjeyya.
root_text.mn45:4.4: Atha kho, bhikkhave, tasmiṁ sāle adhivatthāya devatāya mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā ārāmadevatā vanadevatā rukkhadevatā osadhitiṇavanappatīsu adhivatthā devatā saṅgamma samāgamma evaṁ samassāseyyuṁ:
root_text.mn45:4.6: appeva nāmetaṁ māluvābījaṁ moro vā gileyya, mago vā khādeyya, davaḍāho vā ḍaheyya, vanakammikā vā uddhareyyuṁ, upacikā vā uṭṭhaheyyuṁ, abījaṁ vā panassā’ti.
root_text.mn45:4.7: Atha kho taṁ, bhikkhave, māluvābījaṁ neva moro gileyya, na mago khādeyya, na davaḍāho ḍaheyya, na vanakammikā uddhareyyuṁ, na upacikā uṭṭhaheyyuṁ, bījañca panassa taṁ pāvussakena meghena abhippavuṭṭhaṁ sammadeva viruheyya.
root_text.mn45:4.8: Sāssa māluvālatā taruṇā mudukā lomasā vilambinī, sā taṁ sālaṁ upaniseveyya.
root_text.mn45:4.9: Atha kho, bhikkhave, tasmiṁ sāle adhivatthāya devatāya evamassa:
root_text.mn45:4.10: ‘kiṁsu nāma te bhonto mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā ārāmadevatā vanadevatā rukkhadevatā osadhitiṇavanappatīsu adhivatthā devatā māluvābīje anāgatabhayaṁ sampassamānā saṅgamma samāgamma evaṁ samassāsesuṁ:
root_text.mn45:4.12: appeva nāmetaṁ māluvābījaṁ moro vā gileyya, mago vā khādeyya, davaḍāho vā ḍaheyya, vanakammikā vā uddhareyyuṁ, upacikā vā uṭṭhaheyyuṁ, abījaṁ vā panassā”ti;
root_text.mn45:4.13: sukho imissā māluvālatāya taruṇāya mudukāya lomasāya vilambiniyā samphasso’ti.
root_text.mn45:4.15: Sā taṁ sālaṁ anupariharitvā upari viṭabhiṁ kareyya.
root_text.mn45:4.17: Oghanaṁ janetvā ye tassa sālassa mahantā mahantā khandhā te padāleyya.
root_text.mn45:4.18: Atha kho, bhikkhave, tasmiṁ sāle adhivatthāya devatāya evamassa:
root_text.mn45:4.19: ‘idaṁ kho te bhonto mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā ārāmadevatā vanadevatā rukkhadevatā osadhitiṇavanappatīsu adhivatthā devatā māluvābīje anāgatabhayaṁ sampassamānā saṅgamma samāgamma evaṁ samassāsesuṁ:
root_text.mn45:4.20: “mā bhavaṁ bhāyi mā bhavaṁ bhāyi, appeva nāmetaṁ māluvābījaṁ moro vā gileyya, mago vā khādeyya, davaḍāho vā ḍaheyya, vanakammikā vā uddhareyyuṁ, upacikā vā uṭṭhaheyyuṁ abījaṁ vā panassā”ti.

root_text.mn45:4.29: Te kāmesu pātabyataṁ āpajjitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjanti.

root_text.mn45:5.1: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ?
root_text.mn45:5.2: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco acelako hoti muttācāro hatthāpalekhano, naehibhaddantiko, natiṭṭhabhaddantiko, nābhihaṭaṁ, na uddissakataṁ, na nimantanaṁ sādiyati,
root_text.mn45:5.3: so na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na eḷakamantaraṁ, na daṇḍamantaraṁ, na musalamantaraṁ, na dvinnaṁ bhuñjamānānaṁ, na gabbhiniyā, na pāyamānāya, na purisantaragatāya, na saṅkittīsu, na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti, na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī, na macchaṁ, na maṁsaṁ, na suraṁ, na merayaṁ, na thusodakaṁ pivati.
root_text.mn45:5.4: So ekāgāriko vā hoti ekālopiko, dvāgāriko vā hoti dvālopiko …pe… sattāgāriko vā hoti sattālopiko.
root_text.mn45:5.5: Ekissāpi dattiyā yāpeti, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpeti … sattahipi dattīhi yāpeti.
root_text.mn45:5.6: Ekāhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti, dvīhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti … sattāhikampi āhāraṁ āhāreti. Iti evarūpaṁ addhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
root_text.mn45:5.7: So sākabhakkho vā hoti, sāmākabhakkho vā hoti, nīvārabhakkho vā hoti, daddulabhakkho vā hoti, haṭabhakkho vā hoti, kaṇabhakkho vā hoti, ācāmabhakkho vā hoti, piññākabhakkho vā hoti, tiṇabhakkho vā hoti, gomayabhakkho vā hoti, vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī.
root_text.mn45:5.8: So sāṇānipi dhāreti, masāṇānipi dhāreti, chavadussānipi dhāreti, paṁsukūlānipi dhāreti, tirīṭānipi dhāreti, ajinampi dhāreti, ajinakkhipampi dhāreti, kusacīrampi dhāreti, vākacīrampi dhāreti, phalakacīrampi dhāreti, kesakambalampi dhāreti, vāḷakambalampi dhāreti, ulūkapakkhampi dhāreti,
root_text.mn45:5.14: Iti evarūpaṁ anekavihitaṁ kāyassa ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
root_text.mn45:5.15: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati.
root_text.mn45:5.16: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ.
root_text.mn45:6.1: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākaṁ?
root_text.mn45:6.2: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pakatiyā tibbarāgajātiko hoti, so abhikkhaṇaṁ rāgajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
root_text.mn45:6.3: pakatiyā tibbadosajātiko hoti, so abhikkhaṇaṁ dosajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
root_text.mn45:6.4: pakatiyā tibbamohajātiko hoti, so abhikkhaṇaṁ mohajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.mn45:6.5: So sahāpi dukkhena, sahāpi domanassena, assumukhopi rudamāno paripuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carati.
root_text.mn45:6.6: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
root_text.mn45:6.7: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākaṁ.
root_text.mn45:7.1: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhañceva āyatiñca sukhavipākaṁ?
root_text.mn45:7.2: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pakatiyā na tibbarāgajātiko hoti, so na abhikkhaṇaṁ rāgajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
root_text.mn45:7.3: pakatiyā na tibbadosajātiko hoti, so na abhikkhaṇaṁ dosajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
root_text.mn45:7.4: pakatiyā na tibbamohajātiko hoti, so na abhikkhaṇaṁ mohajaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.mn45:7.5: So vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn45:7.6: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …pe…
root_text.mn45:7.9: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.
root_text.mn45:7.10: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhañceva āyatiñca sukhavipākaṁ.
root_text.mn45:7.13: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn45:0.2: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices
translation_text.mn45:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn45:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn45:2.1: “Mendicants, there are these four ways of taking up practices.
translation_text.mn45:2.3: There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain.
translation_text.mn45:2.4: There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.
translation_text.mn45:2.5: There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure.
translation_text.mn45:2.6: There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure.
translation_text.mn45:3.1: And what is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain?
translation_text.mn45:3.2: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
translation_text.mn45:3.4: They throw themselves into sensual pleasures,
translation_text.mn45:3.5: cavorting with female wanderers with jeweled bands in their hair.
translation_text.mn45:3.7: ‘What future danger do those ascetics and brahmins see in sensual pleasures that they speak of giving up sensual pleasures, and advocate the complete understanding of sensual pleasures?
translation_text.mn45:3.8: Pleasant is the touch of this female wanderer’s arm, tender, soft, and downy!’ And they throw themselves into sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn45:3.9: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn45:3.10: And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings.
translation_text.mn45:3.12: ‘This is that future danger that those ascetics and brahmins saw. For it is because of sensual pleasures that I’m feeling painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings.’
translation_text.mn45:4.1: Suppose that in the last month of summer a camel’s foot creeper pod were to burst open
translation_text.mn45:4.2: and a seed were to fall at the root of a sal tree.
translation_text.mn45:4.3: Then the deity haunting that sal tree would become apprehensive and nervous.
translation_text.mn45:4.4: But their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin—deities of the parks, forests, trees, and those who haunt the herbs, grass, and big trees—would come together to reassure them,
translation_text.mn45:4.5: ‘Do not fear, sir, do not fear!
translation_text.mn45:4.6: Hopefully that seed will be swallowed by a peacock, or eaten by a deer, or burnt by a forest fire, or picked up by a lumberjack, or eaten by termites, or it may not even be fertile.’
translation_text.mn45:4.7: But none of these things happened. And the seed was fertile, so that when the monsoon clouds soaked it with rain, it sprouted.
translation_text.mn45:4.8: And the creeper wound its tender, soft, and downy tendrils around that sal tree.
translation_text.mn45:4.10: ‘What future danger did my friends see when they said:
translation_text.mn45:4.11: “Do not fear, sir, do not fear!
translation_text.mn45:4.12: Hopefully that seed will be swallowed by a peacock, or eaten by a deer, or burnt by a forest fire, or picked up by a lumberjack, or eaten by termites, or it may not even be fertile.”
translation_text.mn45:4.13: Pleasant is the touch of this creeper’s tender, soft, and downy tendrils.’
translation_text.mn45:4.14: Then the creeper enfolded the sal tree,
translation_text.mn45:4.17: and split apart all the main branches.
translation_text.mn45:4.19: ‘This is the future danger that my friends saw!
translation_text.mn45:4.21: It’s because of that camel’s foot creeper seed that I’m feeling painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings.’
translation_text.mn45:4.22: In the same way, there are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view: ‘There’s nothing wrong with sensual pleasures’ …
translation_text.mn45:4.34: This is called the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain.
translation_text.mn45:5.1: And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain?
translation_text.mn45:5.2: It’s when someone goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on their behalf, or an invitation for a meal.
translation_text.mn45:5.3: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.
translation_text.mn45:5.4: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
translation_text.mn45:5.5: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
translation_text.mn45:5.6: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
translation_text.mn45:5.7: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
translation_text.mn45:5.8: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
translation_text.mn45:5.9: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.
translation_text.mn45:5.10: They constantly stand, turning down seats.
translation_text.mn45:5.11: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
translation_text.mn45:5.12: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.
translation_text.mn45:5.13: They’re devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including at dusk.
translation_text.mn45:5.14: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.
translation_text.mn45:5.15: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn45:5.16: This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.
translation_text.mn45:6.1: And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure?
translation_text.mn45:6.2: It’s when someone is ordinarily full of acute greed, hate, and delusion. They often feel the pain and sadness that greed, hate, and delusion bring.
translation_text.mn45:6.5: They lead the full and pure spiritual life in pain and sadness, weeping, with tearful faces.
translation_text.mn45:6.6: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn45:6.7: This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure.
translation_text.mn45:7.1: And what is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure?
translation_text.mn45:7.2: It’s when someone is not ordinarily full of acute greed, hate, and delusion. They rarely feel the pain and sadness that greed, hate, and delusion bring.
translation_text.mn45:7.5: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption …
translation_text.mn45:7.9: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn45:7.10: This is called the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure.
translation_text.mn45:7.11: These are the four ways of taking up practices.”
translation_text.mn45:7.12: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn45:7.13: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
